attributes.name: Ember
attributes.description:
All Ember methods and functions are defined inside of this namespace. You
generally should not add new properties to this namespace as it may be
overwritten by future versions of Ember.

You can also use the shorthand `Em` instead of `Ember`.

Ember-Runtime is a framework that provides core functions for Ember including
cross-platform functions, support for property observing and objects. Its
focus is on small size and performance. You can use this in place of or
along-side other cross-platform libraries such as jQuery.

The core Runtime framework is based on the jQuery API with a number of
performance optimizations.

methods.name: assert

params.name: desc
params.description:
A description of the assertion. This will become
  the text of the Error thrown if the assertion fails.

params.name: test
params.description:
Must be truthy for the assertion to pass. If
  falsy, an exception will be thrown.

methods.description:
Display a warning with the provided message. Ember build tools will
remove any calls to `Ember.warn()` when doing a production build.
methods.name: warn

params.name: message
params.description: A warning to display.

params.name: test
params.description:
An optional boolean. If falsy, the warning
  will be displayed.

methods.description:
Display a debug notice. Ember build tools will remove any calls to
`Ember.debug()` when doing a production build.

```javascript
Ember.debug('I\'m a debug notice!');
```
methods.name: debug

params.name: message
params.description: A debug message to display.

methods.description:
Display a deprecation warning with the provided message and a stack trace
(Chrome and Firefox only). Ember build tools will remove any calls to
`Ember.deprecate()` when doing a production build.
methods.name: deprecate

params.name: message
params.description: A description of the deprecation.

params.name: test
params.description:
An optional boolean. If falsy, the deprecation
  will be displayed.

methods.description:
Alias an old, deprecated method with its new counterpart.

Display a deprecation warning with the provided message and a stack trace
(Chrome and Firefox only) when the assigned method is called.

Ember build tools will not remove calls to `Ember.deprecateFunc()`, though
no warnings will be shown in production.

```javascript
Ember.oldMethod = Ember.deprecateFunc('Please use the new, updated method', Ember.newMethod);
```
methods.name: deprecateFunc

params.name: message
params.description: A description of the deprecation.

params.name: func
params.description: The new function called to replace its deprecated counterpart.

return.description: a new function that wrapped the original function with a deprecation warning

methods.name: runInDebug

params.name: func
params.description: The function to be executed.

methods.description:
If a path starts with a reserved keyword, returns the root
that should be used.
methods.name: normalizePath

methods.description:
Returns true if the provided path is global (e.g., `MyApp.fooController.bar`)
instead of local (`foo.bar.baz`).
methods.name: isGlobalPath

return.description: Boolean

methods.description:
Global helper method to create a new binding. Just pass the root object
along with a `to` and `from` path to create and connect the binding.
methods.name: bind

params.name: obj
params.description: The root object of the transform.

params.name: to
params.description:
The path to the 'to' side of the binding.
  Must be relative to obj.

params.name: from
params.description:
The path to the 'from' side of the binding.
  Must be relative to obj or a global path.

return.description: binding instance

params.name: obj
params.description: The root object of the transform.

params.name: to
params.description:
The path to the 'to' side of the binding.
  Must be relative to obj.

params.name: from
params.description:
The path to the 'from' side of the binding.
  Must be relative to obj or a global path.

return.description: binding instance

methods.description:
This helper returns a new property descriptor that wraps the passed
computed property function. You can use this helper to define properties
with mixins or via `Ember.defineProperty()`.

The function you pass will be used to both get and set property values.
The function should accept two parameters, key and value. If value is not
undefined you should set the value first. In either case return the
current value of the property.
methods.name: computed

params.name: func
params.description: The computed property function.

return.description: property descriptor instance

methods.description:
Returns the cached value for a property, if one exists.
This can be useful for peeking at the value of a computed
property that is generated lazily, without accidentally causing
it to be created.
methods.name: cacheFor

params.name: obj
params.description: the object whose property you want to check

params.name: key
params.description:
the name of the property whose cached value you want
  to return

return.description: the cached value

methods.name: computed.empty

return.description:
computed property which negate
the original value for property

methods.description:
A computed property that returns true if the value of the dependent
property is NOT null, an empty string, empty array, or empty function.

Note: When using `computed.notEmpty` to watch an array make sure to
use the `array.[]` syntax so the computed can subscribe to transitions
from empty to non-empty states.

Example

```javascript
var Hamster = Ember.Object.extend({
  hasStuff: Ember.computed.notEmpty('backpack.[]')
});

var hamster = Hamster.create({ backpack: ['Food', 'Sleeping Bag', 'Tent'] });

hamster.get('hasStuff');         // true
hamster.get('backpack').clear(); // []
hamster.get('hasStuff');         // false
```
methods.name: computed.notEmpty

return.description:
computed property which returns true if
original value for property is not empty.

methods.name: computed.none

return.description:
computed property which
returns true if original value for property is null or undefined.

methods.name: computed.not

return.description:
computed property which returns
inverse of the original value for property

methods.name: computed.bool

return.description:
computed property which converts
to boolean the original value for property

methods.name: computed.match

return.description:
computed property which match
the original value for property against a given RegExp

methods.name: computed.equal

return.description:
computed property which returns true if
the original value for property is equal to the given value.

methods.name: computed.gt

return.description:
computed property which returns true if
the original value for property is greater then given value.

methods.name: computed.gte

return.description:
computed property which returns true if
the original value for property is greater or equal then given value.

methods.name: computed.lt

return.description:
computed property which returns true if
the original value for property is less then given value.

methods.name: computed.lte

return.description:
computed property which returns true if
the original value for property is less or equal then given value.

methods.name: computed.and

return.description:
computed property which performs
a logical `and` on the values of all the original values for properties.

methods.name: computed.or

return.description:
computed property which performs
a logical `or` on the values of all the original values for properties.

methods.name: computed.any

return.description:
computed property which returns
the first truthy value of given list of properties.

methods.name: computed.collect

return.description:
computed property which maps
values of all passed properties in to an array.

methods.name: computed.alias

return.description:
computed property which creates an
alias to the original value for property.

methods.name: computed.oneWay

return.description:
computed property which creates a
one way computed property to the original value for property.

methods.description:
This is a more semantically meaningful alias of `computed.oneWay`,
whose name is somewhat ambiguous as to which direction the data flows.
methods.name: computed.reads

return.description:
computed property which creates a
  one way computed property to the original value for property.

methods.name: computed.readOnly

return.description:
computed property which creates a
one way computed property to the original value for property.

methods.name: computed.defaultTo

return.description:
computed property which acts like
a standard getter and setter, but defaults to the value from `defaultPath`.

methods.description: Empty function. Useful for some operations. Always returns `this`.

methods.description: Add an event listener

params.name: targetOrMethod
params.description: A target object or a function

params.name: method

params.name: once

methods.description:
Remove an event listener

Arguments should match those passed to `Ember.addListener`.
methods.name: removeListener

params.name: targetOrMethod
params.description: A target object or a function

params.name: method
params.description: A function or the name of a function to be called on `target`

methods.description:
Suspend listener during callback.

This should only be used by the target of the event listener
when it is taking an action that would cause the event, e.g.
an object might suspend its property change listener while it is
setting that property.
methods.name: suspendListener

params.name: targetOrMethod
params.description: A target object or a function

params.name: method
params.description: A function or the name of a function to be called on `target`

methods.description: Suspends multiple listeners during a callback.
methods.name: suspendListeners

params.name: eventName
params.description: Array of event names

params.name: targetOrMethod
params.description: A target object or a function

params.name: method
params.description: A function or the name of a function to be called on `target`

methods.description: Return a list of currently watched events
methods.name: watchedEvents

methods.description:
Send an event. The execution of suspended listeners
is skipped, and once listeners are removed. A listener without
a target is executed on the passed object. If an array of actions
is not passed, the actions stored on the passed object are invoked.
methods.name: sendEvent

params.name: params
params.description: Optional parameters for each listener.

params.name: actions
params.description: Optional array of actions (listeners).

return.description: true

methods.name: on

return.description: func

methods.description:
A value is blank if it is empty or a whitespace string.

```javascript
Ember.isBlank();                // true
Ember.isBlank(null);            // true
Ember.isBlank(undefined);       // true
Ember.isBlank('');              // true
Ember.isBlank([]);              // true
Ember.isBlank('\n\t');          // true
Ember.isBlank('  ');            // true
Ember.isBlank({});              // false
Ember.isBlank('\n\t Hello');    // false
Ember.isBlank('Hello world');   // false
Ember.isBlank([1,2,3]);         // false
```
methods.name: isBlank

params.name: obj
params.description: Value to test

methods.description:
Verifies that a value is `null` or an empty string, empty array,
or empty function.

Constrains the rules on `Ember.isNone` by returning false for empty
string and empty arrays.

```javascript
Ember.isEmpty();                // true
Ember.isEmpty(null);            // true
Ember.isEmpty(undefined);       // true
Ember.isEmpty('');              // true
Ember.isEmpty([]);              // true
Ember.isEmpty('Adam Hawkins');  // false
Ember.isEmpty([0,1,2]);         // false
```
methods.name: isEmpty

params.name: obj
params.description: Value to test

methods.description:
Returns true if the passed value is null or undefined. This avoids errors
from JSLint complaining about use of ==, which can be technically
confusing.

```javascript
Ember.isNone();              // true
Ember.isNone(null);          // true
Ember.isNone(undefined);     // true
Ember.isNone('');            // false
Ember.isNone([]);            // false
Ember.isNone(function() {});  // false
```
methods.name: isNone

params.name: obj
params.description: Value to test

params.name: original
params.description: The object to merge into

params.name: updates
params.description: The object to copy properties from

return.description: obj

aliasMethod

params.description: name of the method to alias

return.description: func

return.description: func

return.description: func

methods.description: Identical to `Object.create()`. Implements if not available natively.
methods.name: create
defineProperty

params.name: obj
params.description: the object to define this property on. This may be a prototype.

params.name: keyName
params.description: the name of the property

params.name: desc
params.description:
an instance of `Ember.Descriptor` (typically a
  computed property) or an ES5 descriptor.
  You must provide this or `data` but not both.

params.name: data
params.description:
something other than a descriptor, that will
  become the explicit value of this property.

methods.description:
This function is called just before an object property is about to change.
It will notify any before observers and prepare caches among other things.

Normally you will not need to call this method directly but if for some
reason you can't directly watch a property you can invoke this method
manually along with `Ember.propertyDidChange()` which you should call just
after the property value changes.
methods.name: propertyWillChange

params.name: obj
params.description: The object with the property that will change

params.name: keyName
params.description: The property key (or path) that will change.

methods.description:
This function is called just after an object property has changed.
It will notify any observers and clear caches among other things.

Normally you will not need to call this method directly but if for some
reason you can't directly watch a property you can invoke this method
manually along with `Ember.propertyWillChange()` which you should call just
before the property value changes.
methods.name: propertyDidChange

params.name: obj
params.description: The object with the property that will change

params.name: keyName
params.description: The property key (or path) that will change.

methods.name: changeProperties

methods.description:
Gets the value of a property on an object. If the property is computed,
the function will be invoked. If the property is not defined but the
object implements the `unknownProperty` method then that will be invoked.

If you plan to run on IE8 and older browsers then you should use this
method anytime you want to retrieve a property on an object that you don't
know for sure is private. (Properties beginning with an underscore '_'
are considered private.)

On all newer browsers, you only need to use this method to retrieve
properties if the property might not be defined on the object and you want
to respect the `unknownProperty` handler. Otherwise you can ignore this
method.

Note that if the object itself is `undefined`, this method will throw
an error.
methods.name: get

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to retrieve from.

params.name: keyName
params.description: The property key to retrieve

return.description: the property value or `null`.

methods.description:
Normalizes a target/path pair to reflect that actual target/path that should
be observed, etc. This takes into account passing in global property
paths (i.e. a path beginning with a captial letter not defined on the
target).
methods.name: normalizeTuple

params.name: target
params.description: The current target. May be `null`.

params.name: path
params.description: A path on the target or a global property path.

return.description: a temporary array with the normalized target/path pair.

methods.description:
Sets the value of a property on an object, respecting computed properties
and notifying observers and other listeners of the change. If the
property is not defined but the object implements the `setUnknownProperty`
method then that will be invoked as well.
methods.name: set

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to modify.

params.name: keyName
params.description: The property key to set

params.name: value
params.description: The value to set

return.description: the passed value.

methods.description:
Error-tolerant form of `Ember.set`. Will not blow up if any part of the
chain is `undefined`, `null`, or destroyed.

This is primarily used when syncing bindings, which may try to update after
an object has been destroyed.
methods.name: trySet

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to modify.

params.name: path
params.description: The property path to set

params.name: value
params.description: The value to set

methods.name: setProperties

return.description: self

methods.description:
Generates a new guid, optionally saving the guid to the object that you
pass in. You will rarely need to use this method. Instead you should
call `Ember.guidFor(obj)`, which return an existing guid if available.
methods.name: generateGuid

params.name: obj
params.description:
Object the guid will be used for. If passed in, the guid will
  be saved on the object and reused whenever you pass the same object
  again.

  If no object is passed, just generate a new guid.

params.name: prefix
params.description:
Prefix to place in front of the guid. Useful when you want to
  separate the guid into separate namespaces.

return.description: the guid

methods.description:
Returns a unique id for the object. If the object does not yet have a guid,
one will be assigned to it. You can call this on any object,
`Ember.Object`-based or not, but be aware that it will add a `_guid`
property.

You can also use this method on DOM Element objects.
methods.name: guidFor

params.name: obj
params.description: any object, string, number, Element, or primitive

return.description: the unique guid for this instance.

methods.description:
Retrieves the meta hash for an object. If `writable` is true ensures the
hash is writable for this object as well.

The meta object contains information about computed property descriptors as
well as any watched properties and other information. You generally will
not access this information directly but instead work with higher level
methods that manipulate this hash indirectly.
methods.name: meta

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to retrieve meta for

params.name: writable
params.description:
Pass `false` if you do not intend to modify
  the meta hash, allowing the method to avoid making an unnecessary copy.

return.description: the meta hash for an object

methods.tagname:
In order to store defaults for a class, a prototype may need to create
a default meta object, which will be inherited by any objects instantiated
from the class's constructor.

However, the properties of that meta object are only shallow-cloned,
so if a property is a hash (like the event system's `listeners` hash),
it will by default be shared across all instances of that class.

This method allows extensions to deeply clone a series of nested hashes or
other complex objects. For instance, the event system might pass
`['listeners', 'foo:change', 'ember157']` to `prepareMetaPath`, which will
walk down the keys provided.

For each key, if the key does not exist, it is created. If it already
exists and it was inherited from its constructor, the constructor's
key is cloned.

You can also pass false for `writable`, which will simply return
undefined if `prepareMetaPath` discovers any part of the path that
shared or undefined.
methods.name: metaPath

params.name: obj
params.description: The object whose meta we are examining

params.name: path
params.description: An array of keys to walk down

params.name: writable
params.description:
whether or not to create a new meta
  (or meta property) if one does not already exist or if it's
  shared with its constructor

methods.description:
Wraps the passed function so that `this._super` will point to the superFunc
when the function is invoked. This is the primitive we use to implement
calls to super.
methods.name: wrap

params.name: func
params.description: The function to call

params.name: superFunc
params.description: The super function.

return.description: wrapped function.

methods.description:
Returns true if the passed object is an array or Array-like.

Ember Array Protocol:

  - the object has an objectAt property
  - the object is a native Array
  - the object is an Object, and has a length property

Unlike `Ember.typeOf` this method returns true even if the passed object is
not formally array but appears to be array-like (i.e. implements `Ember.Array`)

```javascript
Ember.isArray();                                          // false
Ember.isArray([]);                                        // true
Ember.isArray(Ember.ArrayProxy.create({ content: [] }));  // true
```
methods.name: isArray

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to test

return.description: true if the passed object is an array or Array-like

methods.description:
Forces the passed object to be part of an array. If the object is already
an array or array-like, returns the object. Otherwise adds the object to
an array. If obj is `null` or `undefined`, returns an empty array.

```javascript
Ember.makeArray();            // []
Ember.makeArray(null);        // []
Ember.makeArray(undefined);   // []
Ember.makeArray('lindsay');   // ['lindsay']
Ember.makeArray([1, 2, 42]);  // [1, 2, 42]

var controller = Ember.ArrayProxy.create({ content: [] });

Ember.makeArray(controller) === controller;  // true
```
methods.name: makeArray

params.name: obj
params.description: the object

methods.description:
Checks to see if the `methodName` exists on the `obj`.

```javascript
var foo = { bar: Ember.K, baz: null };

Ember.canInvoke(foo, 'bar'); // true
Ember.canInvoke(foo, 'baz'); // false
Ember.canInvoke(foo, 'bat'); // false
```
methods.name: canInvoke

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to check for the method

params.name: methodName
params.description: The method name to check for

methods.description:
Checks to see if the `methodName` exists on the `obj`,
and if it does, invokes it with the arguments passed.

```javascript
var d = new Date('03/15/2013');

Ember.tryInvoke(d, 'getTime');              // 1363320000000
Ember.tryInvoke(d, 'setFullYear', [2014]);  // 1394856000000
Ember.tryInvoke(d, 'noSuchMethod', [2014]); // undefined
```
methods.name: tryInvoke

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to check for the method

params.name: methodName
params.description: The method name to check for

params.name: args
params.description: The arguments to pass to the method

return.description: the return value of the invoked method or undefined if it cannot be invoked

methods.name: tryFinally

params.name: tryable
params.description: The function to run the try callback

params.name: finalizer
params.description: The function to run the finally callback

params.name: binding
params.description: The optional calling object. Defaults to 'this'

return.description:
The return value is the that of the finalizer,
unless that value is undefined, in which case it is the return value
of the tryable

methods.name: tryCatchFinally

params.name: tryable
params.description: The function to run the try callback

params.name: catchable
params.description: The function to run the catchable callback

params.name: finalizer
params.description: The function to run the finally callback

params.name: binding
params.description: The optional calling object. Defaults to 'this'

return.description:
The return value is the that of the finalizer,
unless that value is undefined, in which case it is the return value
of the tryable.

methods.description:
Returns a consistent type for the passed item.

Use this instead of the built-in `typeof` to get the type of an item.
It will return the same result across all browsers and includes a bit
more detail. Here is what will be returned:

    | Return Value  | Meaning                                              |
    |---------------|------------------------------------------------------|
    | 'string'      | String primitive or String object.                   |
    | 'number'      | Number primitive or Number object.                   |
    | 'boolean'     | Boolean primitive or Boolean object.                 |
    | 'null'        | Null value                                           |
    | 'undefined'   | Undefined value                                      |
    | 'function'    | A function                                           |
    | 'array'       | An instance of Array                                 |
    | 'regexp'      | An instance of RegExp                                |
    | 'date'        | An instance of Date                                  |
    | 'class'       | An Ember class (created using Ember.Object.extend()) |
    | 'instance'    | An Ember object instance                             |
    | 'error'       | An instance of the Error object                      |
    | 'object'      | A JavaScript object not inheriting from Ember.Object |

Examples:

```javascript
Ember.typeOf();                       // 'undefined'
Ember.typeOf(null);                   // 'null'
Ember.typeOf(undefined);              // 'undefined'
Ember.typeOf('michael');              // 'string'
Ember.typeOf(new String('michael'));  // 'string'
Ember.typeOf(101);                    // 'number'
Ember.typeOf(new Number(101));        // 'number'
Ember.typeOf(true);                   // 'boolean'
Ember.typeOf(new Boolean(true));      // 'boolean'
Ember.typeOf(Ember.makeArray);        // 'function'
Ember.typeOf([1, 2, 90]);             // 'array'
Ember.typeOf(/abc/);                  // 'regexp'
Ember.typeOf(new Date());             // 'date'
Ember.typeOf(Ember.Object.extend());  // 'class'
Ember.typeOf(Ember.Object.create());  // 'instance'
Ember.typeOf(new Error('teamocil'));  // 'error'

// 'normal' JavaScript object
Ember.typeOf({ a: 'b' });             // 'object'
```
methods.name: typeOf

params.name: item
params.description: the item to check

return.description: the type

methods.description:
Convenience method to inspect an object. This method will attempt to
convert the object into a useful string description.

It is a pretty simple implementation. If you want something more robust,
use something like JSDump: https://github.com/NV/jsDump
methods.name: inspect

params.name: obj
params.description: The object you want to inspect.

return.description: A description of the object

methods.description:
Starts watching a property on an object. Whenever the property changes,
invokes `Ember.propertyWillChange` and `Ember.propertyDidChange`. This is the
primitive used by observers and dependent keys; usually you will never call
this method directly but instead use higher level methods like
`Ember.addObserver()`
methods.name: watch

methods.description:
Call on an object when you first beget it from another object. This will
setup any chained watchers on the object instance as needed. This method is
safe to call multiple times.
methods.name: rewatch

methods.description:
Tears down the meta on an object so that it can be garbage collected.
Multiple calls will have no effect.
methods.name: destroy

params.name: obj
params.description: the object to destroy

methods.description: Finds a controller instance.
methods.name: controllerFor

methods.description:
Generates a controller factory

The type of the generated controller factory is derived
from the context. If the context is an array an array controller
is generated, if an object, an object controller otherwise, a basic
controller is generated.

You can customize your generated controllers by defining
`App.ObjectController` or `App.ArrayController`.
methods.name: generateControllerFactory

methods.description:
Generates and instantiates a controller.

The type of the generated controller factory is derived
from the context. If the context is an array an array controller
is generated, if an object, an object controller otherwise, a basic
controller is generated.
methods.name: generateController

methods.description:
Creates a computed property which operates on dependent arrays and
is updated with "one at a time" semantics. When items are added or
removed from the dependent array(s) an array computed only operates
on the change instead of re-evaluating the entire array. This should
return an array, if you'd like to use "one at a time" semantics and
compute some value other then an array look at
`Ember.reduceComputed`.

If there are more than one arguments the first arguments are
considered to be dependent property keys. The last argument is
required to be an options object. The options object can have the
following three properties.

`initialize` - An optional initialize function. Typically this will be used
to set up state on the instanceMeta object.

`removedItem` - A function that is called each time an element is
removed from the array.

`addedItem` - A function that is called each time an element is
added to the array.


The `initialize` function has the following signature:

```javascript
function(array, changeMeta, instanceMeta)
```

`array` - The initial value of the arrayComputed, an empty array.

`changeMeta` - An object which contains meta information about the
computed. It contains the following properties:

   - `property` the computed property
   - `propertyName` the name of the property on the object

`instanceMeta` - An object that can be used to store meta
information needed for calculating your computed. For example a
unique computed might use this to store the number of times a given
element is found in the dependent array.


The `removedItem` and `addedItem` functions both have the following signature:

```javascript
function(accumulatedValue, item, changeMeta, instanceMeta)
```

`accumulatedValue` - The value returned from the last time
`removedItem` or `addedItem` was called or an empty array.

`item` - the element added or removed from the array

`changeMeta` - An object which contains meta information about the
change. It contains the following properties:

  - `property` the computed property
  - `propertyName` the name of the property on the object
  - `index` the index of the added or removed item
  - `item` the added or removed item: this is exactly the same as
    the second arg
  - `arrayChanged` the array that triggered the change. Can be
    useful when depending on multiple arrays.

For property changes triggered on an item property change (when
depKey is something like `someArray.@each.someProperty`),
`changeMeta` will also contain the following property:

  - `previousValues` an object whose keys are the properties that changed on
  the item, and whose values are the item's previous values.

`previousValues` is important Ember coalesces item property changes via
Ember.run.once. This means that by the time removedItem gets called, item has
the new values, but you may need the previous value (eg for sorting &
filtering).

`instanceMeta` - An object that can be used to store meta
information needed for calculating your computed. For example a
unique computed might use this to store the number of times a given
element is found in the dependent array.

The `removedItem` and `addedItem` functions should return the accumulated
value. It is acceptable to not return anything (ie return undefined)
to invalidate the computation. This is generally not a good idea for
arrayComputed but it's used in eg max and min.

Example

```javascript
Ember.computed.map = function(dependentKey, callback) {
  var options = {
    addedItem: function(array, item, changeMeta, instanceMeta) {
      var mapped = callback(item);
      array.insertAt(changeMeta.index, mapped);
      return array;
    },
    removedItem: function(array, item, changeMeta, instanceMeta) {
      array.removeAt(changeMeta.index, 1);
      return array;
    }
  };

  return Ember.arrayComputed(dependentKey, options);
};
```
methods.name: arrayComputed
reduceComputed

methods.description:
A computed property that returns the sum of the value
in the dependent array.
methods.name: computed.sum

return.description: computes the sum of all values in the dependentKey's array

methods.name: computed.max

return.description: computes the largest value in the dependentKey's array

methods.name: computed.min

return.description: computes the smallest value in the dependentKey's array

methods.name: computed.map

return.description: an array mapped via the callback

methods.name: computed.mapBy

return.description: an array mapped to the specified key

methods.name: computed.filter

return.description: the filtered array

methods.name: computed.filterBy

return.description: the filtered array

methods.name: computed.uniq

return.description:
computes a new array with all the
unique elements from the dependent array

methods.description: Alias for [Ember.computed.uniq](/api/#method_computed_uniq).
methods.name: computed.union

return.description:
computes a new array with all the
unique elements from the dependent array

methods.description:
A computed property which returns a new array with all the duplicated
elements from two or more dependent arrays.

Example

```javascript
var obj = Ember.Object.createWithMixins({
  adaFriends: ['Charles Babbage', 'John Hobhouse', 'William King', 'Mary Somerville'],
  charlesFriends: ['William King', 'Mary Somerville', 'Ada Lovelace', 'George Peacock'],
  friendsInCommon: Ember.computed.intersect('adaFriends', 'charlesFriends')
});

obj.get('friendsInCommon'); // ['William King', 'Mary Somerville']
```
methods.name: computed.intersect

return.description:
computes a new array with all the
duplicated elements from the dependent arrays

methods.name: computed.setDiff

return.description:
computes a new array with all the
items from the first dependent array that are not in the second
dependent array

a dependent key to an

return.description:
computes a new sorted array based
on the sort property array or callback function

Called when an Ember.js package (e.g Ember.Handlebars) has finished
loading. Triggers any callbacks registered for this event.

methods.name: A

methods.description:
This will compare two javascript values of possibly different types.
It will tell you which one is greater than the other by returning:

 - -1 if the first is smaller than the second,
 - 0 if both are equal,
 - 1 if the first is greater than the second.

The order is calculated based on `Ember.ORDER_DEFINITION`, if types are different.
In case they have the same type an appropriate comparison for this type is made.

 ```javascript
 Ember.compare('hello', 'hello');  // 0
 Ember.compare('abc', 'dfg');      // -1
 Ember.compare(2, 1);              // 1
 ```
methods.name: compare

params.name: v
params.description: First value to compare

params.name: w
params.description: Second value to compare

return.description: -1 if v < w, 0 if v = w and 1 if v > w.

methods.description:
Creates a clone of the passed object. This function can take just about
any type of object and create a clone of it, including primitive values
(which are not actually cloned because they are immutable).

If the passed object implements the `clone()` method, then this function
will simply call that method and return the result.
methods.name: copy

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to clone

params.name: deep
params.description: If true, a deep copy of the object is made

return.description: The cloned object

methods.description:
Compares two objects, returning true if they are logically equal. This is
a deeper comparison than a simple triple equal. For sets it will compare the
internal objects. For any other object that implements `isEqual()` it will
respect that method.

```javascript
Ember.isEqual('hello', 'hello');  // true
Ember.isEqual(1, 2);              // false
Ember.isEqual([4, 2], [4, 2]);    // false
```
methods.name: isEqual

params.name: a
params.description: first object to compare

params.name: b
params.description: second object to compare

methods.description:
Returns all of the keys defined on an object or hash. This is useful
when inspecting objects for debugging. On browsers that support it, this
uses the native `Object.keys` implementation.
methods.name: keys

return.description: Array containing keys of obj

methods.description: Alias for jQuery

properties.description: Array polyfills to support ES5 features in older browsers.
properties.name: ArrayPolyfills

properties.description:
Debug parameter you can turn on. This will log all bindings that fire to
the console. This should be disabled in production code. Note that you
can also enable this from the console or temporarily.
properties.name: LOG_BINDINGS

properties.description:
Standard environmental variables. You can define these in a global `EmberENV`
variable before loading Ember to control various configuration settings.

For backwards compatibility with earlier versions of Ember the global `ENV`
variable will be used if `EmberENV` is not defined.
properties.name: ENV

properties.description:
Determines whether Ember should enhance some built-in object prototypes to
provide a more friendly API. If enabled, a few methods will be added to
`Function`, `String`, and `Array`. `Object.prototype` will not be enhanced,
which is the one that causes most trouble for people.

In general we recommend leaving this option set to true since it rarely
conflicts with other code. If you need to turn it off however, you can
define an `ENV.EXTEND_PROTOTYPES` config to disable it.
properties.name: EXTEND_PROTOTYPES

properties.description: Determines whether Ember logs a full stack trace during deprecation warnings
properties.name: LOG_STACKTRACE_ON_DEPRECATION

properties.description: Determines whether Ember should add ECMAScript 5 shims to older browsers.
properties.name: SHIM_ES5

properties.description: Determines whether Ember logs info about version of used libraries
properties.name: LOG_VERSION

properties.description:
Previously we used `Ember.$.uuid`, however `$.uuid` has been removed from
jQuery master. We'll just bootstrap our own uuid now.
properties.name: uuid

properties.description: Prefix used for guids through out Ember.
properties.name: GUID_PREFIX

properties.description:
A unique key used to assign guids and other private metadata to objects.
If you inspect an object in your browser debugger you will often see these.
They can be safely ignored.

On browsers that support it, these properties are added with enumeration
disabled so they won't show up when you iterate over your properties.
properties.name: GUID_KEY

properties.description: The key used to store meta information on object for property observing.
properties.name: META_KEY

properties.description:
Defines the hash of localized strings for the current language. Used by
the `Ember.String.loc()` helper. To localize, add string values to this
hash.
properties.name: STRINGS

properties.description:
Global hash of shared templates. This will automatically be populated
by the build tools so that you can store your Handlebars templates in
separate files that get loaded into JavaScript at buildtime.
properties.name: TEMPLATES
